Award.AwardTitle: Exploration of classical-quantum and easy-hard boundaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
A quantum spin, like a classical magnet, can point at any direction, but a collection of quantum spins generally behave in a more exotic way and can point to many more directions than classical spins do. This usually translates to the feature that quantum many-body problems are much harder than classical problems. However, in some physical models, quantum spins, even though they can point to more directions (which originate from large spin magnitudes), turn out to behave much like classical magnets, with only small fluctuations around the direction they point to. It seems that even in the quantum world, there are regions that look more or less like the classical world. Where is the boundary between the classical and quantum territories? When do quantum problems become easy and when do they become hard? These two intimately related questions are the subject of this project. A clear characterization of such a `transition' will help to understand the exotic properties of quantum many-body systems.

The integration of the research findings of this project into education on quantum information and quantum many-body physics will help to nurture a new generation of students with new tools of thinking. This project also includes training of a graduate student and mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher. The planned outreach activities such as giving public lectures, mentoring high school students for summer research projects, and developing materials and activities for high school students in science and mathematics education will complement the research activities and lead to sustaining impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many physics models are difficult to solve, but if solved, can offer insight for deciphering the mystery of physical phenomena. Provable hardness results exist even for classical problems, but the quantum mechanical rules in many-body scenario can allow a problem to be much harder to solve, due to features such as entanglement. The computational complexity can be different for classical (where a coin can be either head of tail up) or quantum (where a coin can be head and tail up at the same time) problems.  This project has explored various scenarios in classical and quantum settings.

In one investigation, we studied how quantum computers can be realized in one dimension, i.e. in a chain of spins (or quantum `dits’, a.k.a. qudits) and what is the compromise between the minimal dit number d vs. the locality number k of consecutive qudits that interact simultaneously. As the locality number k increases, it is expected that the minimum required d in order to be able to quantum compute should decrease. All the cases (d,k) can be represented on a two-dimensional grid and we estimated on this grid the boundary between easy and hard cases in terms of information processing.

A journal paper that describes some of the results was published in

“Hamiltonian quantum computer in one dimension”, Phys. Rev. A 92, 062334 (2015).

In our construction, the Hamiltonian, that describes how qudits interact, can be characterized as the so-called k-local Hamiltonian, also related to the quantum satisfiability (Q-SAT) problems. Hamiltonians naturally arise from quantum spin systems that model, e.g., quantum magnets or particles hopping in a lattice while repelling each other. We therefore also constructed models that are physically motivated and that incorporate symmetry consideration. We obtained eight distinct regions or phases, and understood their physical properties from symmetry viewpoints. However, between certain two regions, the system on the boundary requires substantial scaling of entanglement, implying that they are possibly `difficult'. The findings are presented in

 “Detection of gapped phases of a 1D spin chain with onsite and spatial symmetries”, Phys. Rev. B 94, 045136 (2016).

However, generic Hamiltonians problems usually involve randomness in the interactions or potentials. Extending the study to such generic scenarios, we also constructed another family of one-dimensional Hamiltonians with symmetry imposed in the interaction. Moreover we expanded our study to higher excited states beyond just the ground states. We characterized eigen-states by their entanglement, their symmetry properties, and compared how these properties behave as the chain size increases. In terms of the statistical mechanical perspective, we found three distinct regions in the phase diagram. Two of them are well characterized and distinguished by many properties: one a thermalized phase and the other is the quantum spin-glass (many-body localized) phase. However, the third region possesses properties that cannot be well characterized to be either of the former two. It is possible that this is a region that contains the so-called hard instances in local Hamiltonian problems or Q-SAT. The results were presented in the paper,

"Eigenstate phases with finite on-site non-Abelian symmetry", Phys. Rev. B 96, 165136 (2017).

In several of the above studies, it was important to characterize and quantify entanglement in order to understand the hardness in simulating a quantum system. Therefore, we also developed methods in quantifying entanglement that could be applied in many situations, with results presented in

 "Topological Transitions from Multipartite Entanglement with Tensor Networks: A Procedure for Sharper and Faster Characterization", Phys. Rev. Lett. 113, 257202 (2014)

and

"Holographic encoding of universality in corner spectra", Phys. Rev. B 95, 195170 (2017) .

In one study, we analyzed the gap in a particular Hamiltonian. This was useful in a quantitative way to give progress to an otherwise unproved conjecture regarding the gap. The results were presented in

 "Spectral gaps of Affleck-Kennedy-Lieb-Tasaki Hamiltonians using Tensor Network methods", Phys. Rev. B 88, 245118 (2013).

In addition to quantum problems, we also investigated a classical problem, for which the generic case is known to be hard on the complex plane. We devised a method with controlled approximation to compute the magnetization in the complex magnetic-field plane. This gave insight into the understanding of the system, and the results were published in

 “Density of Yang-Lee zeros in the thermodynamic limit from tensor network methods”, Phys. Rev. B 92, 125132 (2015).

Beside the intellectual merits from the research activities, the PI also provided training for postdoctoral researchers and graduate students. He organized seminars in the interdisciplinary area of quantum information and computation, developed related course materials, and gave public lectures. He supervised high school students for summer research projects and gave physics lectures to a group of high school students attending the summer institute on Stony Brook campus. He also encouraged graduate students and provided opportunities for them to get involved in outreach activities in local communities.
